item.description: Apple‚Äôs Music app needs multiple selection on its playlist editor. It is tedious to remove albums I have listened to from my personal ‚Äúnew music‚Äù playlist. It is easier to manage on iTunes, but I hardly ever listen to music via my Mac anymore.

item.title: Joe Steel's Guide to Mastodon
item.description:
This blog post is a great overview of Mastodon.

In conversations I‚Äôve had over the past week, it‚Äôs become clear that there‚Äôs nothing very self-explanatory about Mastodon as a social network, and that in many ways Twitter users are both prepared and unprepared for the experience. There are a lot of things that are similar in concept, but there‚Äôs more to it when it comes to how it‚Äôs a ‚Äúservice‚Äù that can really throw people for a loop.

I use Mastodon a little, but don‚Äôt really feel strongly one way or another towards the platform. I want to like it more. I was super enthusiastic about its predecessors, like StatusNet (nee Laconica, now GNU Social), but those failed to gain significant momentum, and became overrun with spam.

Despite whatever is new and exciting about Mastodon‚Äôs web UI, open web features, etc., it doesn‚Äôt feel that new or exciting to me. It feels like a better StatusNet. I suppose, though, that I care more about writing and posting content, and owning it, than about the ephemeral and chatty aspects of social networking.

I‚Äôm debugging iOS Files access in SwiftoDo this evening. It feels like ages since I worked on this app. During my 2-week vacation, I was exploring UI and navigation ideas I have for a future version of SwiftoDo.

item.title: It looks like iOS 12 will extend the life of my old iOS hardware
item.description:
I bought my iPad Air 2 almost a year after it was released, only a few months before the first iPad Pro was released. I was a little worried at the time that I would get only a couple years out of it before iOS updates rendered it obsolete. I have been pleasantly surprised that that day has not yet arrived‚Äîand, based on how the iOS 12 beta is running, that day will not arrive for at least another year.

Last night, I finally installed the iOS 12 beta on it, and found the new OS to be smooth, stable, and fast. All my apps (even the ones I wrote!) are working just fine. As Apple promised, UI and animation-related things like scrolling are visibly faster and smoother, too.

I plan to install iOS 12 beta on my iPhone 7 Plus in early September, after I complete my next release of SwiftoDo. Based what I‚Äôm seeing, performance wise, on my even-older iPad Air 2, I‚Äôm looking forward to at least one more year of service from my iPhone 7 Plus, too. (It helps that my phone has a brand new battery and a new screen, thanks to AppleCare Plus.)

item.title: The New Dark Sky App
item.description:
Dark Sky released a ground-up rewrite of their flagship iOS app today.

The most noticeable change is the introduction of a new unified timeline. Rather than separating the forecast onto multiple pages, we now combine the current conditions, next hour rain forecast, next 24 hours, and next week forecasts into a single scrollable view that lets you quickly get to the part of the forecast you care about. This makes it much easier to scan what will happen in the minutes, hours, and days ahead.

Dark Sky version 1.0, which was singularly focused on precipitation warnings and maps for your immediate vicinity, was probably my favorite iteration of the app. It wasn‚Äôt a full-fledged weather app at the time, but its singular focus was useful for me whenever I wanted to step out of the house or office.

I have been using Weather Line, which uses Dark Sky weather data, almost exclusively for the past couple years, because its information layout was denser and more useful. This update may bring me back to Dark Sky, however. I‚Äôm moving it back to my home screen and will give it a go.

I am fully back from vacation now, trying to get back into the swing of things at work. Fortunately for me, I had good people covering for me, and almost nothing I had to do for work over the past two weeks. The mad rush will resume today, I‚Äôm sure. üòÄ
I finally bought MarsEdit 4 today!
My vacation is almost over.

I rewatched ‚ÄúAvengers: Age of Infinity‚Äù and my loved it. I actually liked it better the second time. If 20-year-old me knew that nearly-40-year-old me would prefer comic book movies to nearly everything else‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt think we would be friends.
Today is the big trip up north in the car. It‚Äôs a 5-hour trek that somehow takes my family 12 hours or so each year.
I‚Äôve got only 5 days until vacation. Hopefully I can shift gears from programming and data work for my day job back to writing and coding for my hobbies.
I‚Äôm impressed that my old, USB-2 iPad Camera Connection Kit still seems fast to me.
After this today‚Äôs meeting, my database project has become 10 times larger but 25% simpler. I hope I can still meet my deadline.
My work day started off far more slowly than expected. Therefore, I‚Äôm coding‚Äîmaybe all day‚Äîfor my ‚Äúnumber 3‚Äù project.

I took my (old) Sony RX 100 camera to the splash park to take pictures of the kids and got dozens of great shots. My wife and I looked back at our kids‚Äô baby pictures a little, after looking through today‚Äôs photos, and had a great time doing so tonight.
I beat Bastion tonight. What a great ending. I may do the second playthrough, New Game+, though I may take a break beforehand.
I‚Äôm looking forward to a visit with the family to the county fair tonight. Last year‚Äôs fair was a lot of fun.

I have been seriously considering holding on to my iPhone 7 Plus for a third year. I just got a new screen and a new battery, It looks almost brand new, I still like the camera, I never complain about it being slow, and iOS 12 promises to improve performance when I upgrade to it. I feel the same way about my Series 1 Apple Watch, too, though my desire to upgrade it to whatever model Apple releases next is still a lot higher.
Bastion is so much fun that I bought the developer‚Äôs subsequent game, Transistor.

I spent most of the day coding an Access app for work. I‚Äôm coding VBA now almost like it‚Äôs a proper object-oriented language: lots of tiny classes that do one thing only, basically no repeated code segments, use of design patterns wherever possible, and so on.
I‚Äôm enjoying this week‚Äôs Accidental Tech Podcast.
Blog post: SwiftoDo Development Notes, July 2018

item.title: Introducing my latest iOS app: Simple Call Blocker
item.description:
Simple Call Blocker is a free app for blocking unwanted calls on iOS.

It provides a basic way to block lots of numbers via a CallKit directory extension‚Äìwhich is great for blocking neighbor spam.

Unlike almost every other call blocker out there, mine is completely free and doesn‚Äôt need access to your contacts to work.

Try it out. It‚Äôs free.

If you want to know more, there‚Äôs a website with screenshots and a FAQ. I wrote a blog post describing my motivation for writing it, too.
I replaced my old, crumbling, extra- extra large Grifiti wrist rest with a new one, suitably sized for my tenkeyless keyboard. It was a good move.
üéµ Tonight I‚Äôm working overtime and listening to The Hold Steady, which almost makes it all right.
Vacation is wonderful, but boy does it feel like a due date for everything that‚Äôs open at work.

I left my iPhone at the Apple Store for a screen repair and a new battery. I‚Äôm using my Essential Phone as an actual phone for the first time this afternoon. I do not plan to write a ‚Äúswitching post‚Äù though‚Äîit‚Äôs just temporary. üòÄ

item.title: I find myself shifting my listening time away from podcasts and more toward music lately
item.description:
I started listening to podcasts in 2008. I think, now, I am, for the first time, burnt out on the medium. I listen to a lot of podcasts while I work, but lately I‚Äôve found I can barely remember what the episodes were about shortly after they finish. I think I am tuning them out.

I am paring back my subscriptions down‚Äîway down‚Äîto a few favorites and listening to more music instead. It‚Äôs symmetrical to how I got into podcast listening: I was burnt out on listening to music all day long, and became uninterested in music for several years.
Hot take: The 12.9‚Äù iPad Pro I‚Äôm working on right now is not large enough!
Blog post: On Internet Trolls

üéµ I‚Äôm back to my wired OPPO PM-3 & HA-2 SE headphones stack today, listening to Foreverland, by The Divine Comedy. It‚Äôs an album that slipped by me in 2016. I used to love The Divine Comedy in the late 1990s, and still take Casanova for a spin every six months or so.

item.title: Trial runs for fascism are in full flow
item.description:
This article by Fintan O‚ÄôToole in The Irish Times is a few weeks old now, but I keep thinking about it.

Fascism doesn‚Äôt arise suddenly in an existing democracy. It is not easy to get people to give up their ideas of freedom and civility. You have to do trial runs that, if they are done well, serve two purposes. They get people used to something they may initially recoil from; and they allow you to refine and calibrate. This is what is happening now and we would be fools not to see it.

Mr. O‚ÄôToole lays out a simple and convincing argument outlining ideas that I have been mulling over in my head, but not writing much about, since Trump‚Äôs election on November 8, 2016. What has happened‚Äîat an accelerating pace, I think, since last year‚Äîis that the bounds of what is considered normal have been stretched so far into what was previously outrageous that I fear there is no going back. If Trump and the Republican Party are proving that the U.S. president is above the law, and that much of what governed the government was merely tradition, which is disposable for political expediency, then what, if anything, will constrain the power and the actions of future U.S. presidents?
Oh! I‚Äôm getting a Microsoft Office update this morning. I wonder what office suites were like in the year 2016‚Ä¶
I have pared back my Twitter following list to Lin-Manuel Miranda and Ole Begemann, which is sometimes weird and sometimes delightful, the few moments per week I check in on them.

I‚Äôm super pleased listening to these V-Moda Crossfade 2 Codex Edition headphones all day at work, over Bluetooth. (Wireless use is pretty rare for me.) Great sound. Great isolation. The top of my head is a little sore from the headband, though. (They are kind of heavy.) üéß

I checked out the new MacBook Pros at the Apple Store. The new keyboard looks (feels) like a winner to me. It is quieter, and there‚Äôs a good chance it won‚Äôt have the same reliability problem as the prior generation. I would prefer a 15‚Äù one without the TouchBar, though, but don‚Äôt plan to buy one until my 2015 rMBP breaks or is no longer supported.

Our appointment for family photos at the park got canceled today due to heavy rain. We ended up shopping and eating pancakes instead. Not a bad trade-off for the day, but I would have liked to have the photos later.

I both love and hate articles like ‚ÄúThe New York Yankees Are a Moral Abomination‚Äù. Handwringing, declinist arguments about baseball are almost as old as baseball itself. ‚ÄúBaseball is in decline‚Äù is part of its brand‚Äîpart that needs to go away, I think.

Baseball is awesome. The players are very skillful, play a game that doesn‚Äôt involve hurting each other, and legitimately appear to be enjoying themselves.

I started replaying Bastion on my IPad Pro tonight. I bought it years ago and never finished it. I‚Äôm using a controller and headphones this time around, which improve the experience. I‚Äôm better at combat than I used to be, but a lot worse at the proving grounds challenges.
If I was smart, I would save $100/month for a new MacBook every 4 years or so. I am not smart.
Blog post: Re-committing to Pinboard, after many months away
The App Store gods are not smiling on me this week. My new app got rejected again. Now things are screwed up in a way I cannot fix. Hopefully it will all work out eventually.
SwiftoDo 2.13.2 is now available in the App Store. It fixes a Reminders import bug.
Just got an email from Apple. My new app is in review for the second time. Hopefully it doesn‚Äôt get rejected again, and I can finally launch it. ü§û
When will it not be news that people act like asshats on Twitter?

A git commit somehow disappeared, eradicating all my app code and obliterating at least one evening‚Äôs worth of work. I cracked open a Guinness, restored a backup from Arq, recovered about 80% of my work, and re-did the rest. I‚Äôm happy I didn‚Äôt lose my cool.
I found a headphone case whose brand name really gets at my peculiar affliction.
Based on this article, I predict that HBO is going to start to get a lot worse under its new ownership (AT&T). I hope I am wrong.

Salsas at my family‚Äôs favorite Mexican restaurant:

  • Queso: not hot
  • Verde: not hot
  • Ranchero: not hot
  • Guajillo: not hot
  • Arbol: way too hot!

Apple‚Äôs App Review rejected my new app, primarily because its name had the word ‚Äúfree‚Äù in it. While that‚Äôs not the end of the world, it will delay the app‚Äôs release for at least a couple days, as I figure out a new name and the best way to handle everything in App Store Connect.
